Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Block Copolymer Compatibilizers for Controlled Morphology and Interfacial Properties in Polymer-Fullerene Blends

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration: The PIs have previously found that a hierarchical morphology of donor and acceptor domains led to a high yield of electron transfer, enhanced exciton dissociation, and a high power conversion efficiency (PCE). In this proposal, they seek to combine theory and experiments in a coordinated approach to manipulate the nanostructured hierarchical morphologies in a controlled manner in order to quantify the influence of different morphological length scales on the optoelectronic properties and the efficiencies of solar cells composed of a semi-conducting donor and the fullerene acceptor system, PCBM. One way to ensure increased contact between the donor and acceptor phases is to use block copolymers (BCP), PTB7, as ?compatiblizers? to meld the two phases. Their approach is to find what the ?design rules? are for OPVs by undertaking a systematic combined experimental-theoretical investigation for designing efficient compatibilizers in the context of OPV applications. Their general plan is to synthesize PTB7 block copolymers, measure the รท-interaction parameter between model polymer blocks, PTB7, and fullerene in thin film, multilayer blends, then elucidate and correlate the thermodynamics and microstructures of the BHJ blends to the morphology and optoelectronic properties of bulk heterojunction photovoltaics with PTB7 block copolymer compatibilizers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project involved a collaborative experimental and computational research to design additives which can be added to organic solar cells to improve their efficiencies. Organic solar cells are a class of solar cells which invoke carbon based compounts such as polymers and other organic molecules for converting sunlight to electricity. Such materials are of interest due to their potential for fabricating flexible displays and solar cells. However, such solar cells still lag considerably behind their silicon counterparts in their efficiency and performance. In this collaborative project, we developed a scheme to design materials termed as block copolymers which can be added to the organic solar cells to modulate the performance of such solar cells. In this regard, we devloped new computer simulation tools, whose predictions can serve as a guide to narrow and/or identify parameteric regions where better performance be achieved. Such predictions were then implemented in the experiments to identify new formulations with improved performance. The practical impacts of this project are to be in the context of the ideas developed and a new approach to modulate the efficiency of the solar cells. 

 

This project involved a number of opportunities for education and training for STEM workforce. Atleast two full time Phd students were trained in this project and have embarked on their careers in industry. Moreover, a number of undergraduate were involved in this research, which served to provide them with an experience beyond those offered in traditional classrooms. The outcomes of research were also integrated as examples within the classes taught by the project PIs. In addition, the results were diseeminated widely in peer-reviewed journals and conference proceedings.

 


Last Modified: 07/24/2017
Modified by: Venkat Ganesan
